bibl.title: Letter from Frederick L. Rath, Jr., to Philip Showalter Hench, May 23, 1952

div1.p: Rath informs Hench that the National Trust for Historic Preservation does not deem it possible to take ownership of the Quinta San Jose, as Rojas would prefer, but will cooperate with preservation efforts. He thinks any preservation association must be chartered in Cuba, but might have strong American representation.

div1.head: Letter from Frederick L. Rath, Jr., to Philip Showalter Hench, May 23, 1952
div1.opener:
National Trust for Historic Preservation
712 Jackson Place, N. W. · Washington 6, D. C.
Chairman, Board of Trustees
DAVID E. FINLEY
Vice Chairmen, Board of Trustees
U. S. GRANT, 3RD
GEORGE A. McANENY
Secretary
Treasurer
RONALD F.LEE
C. F. JACOBSEN
Telephone:
NATIONAL 2192
Administrator
HENRY H. SURFACE
Director
FREDERICK L. RATH, JR.
May 23, 1952
Dr. Philip S. Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minnesota
Dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
I know that you will be interested to hear about the results
of the discussion of Quinta San Jose and associated problems at the
recent Trustees meeting. The Trustees of the National Trust felt that
it would be possible for them to cooperate informally with the indi-
viduals and any group that might be formed to assure the preservation
of Quinta San Jose. They did not deem it possible to consider, how-
ever, outright ownership by the National Trust, which was a tentative
suggestion of Senora Rojas.

I cannot say clearly how far along the line toward an even-
tual solution this brings us. The situation in Cuba is confused. I
have not yet heard from Senora Rojas in regard to the study that Dr.
Saladrigas was to make of the present thought on Building No. 1. Al-
though it is somewhat academic. I think that the future may bring
about this situation: If the Cuban government abandons its plans for
a memorial at the land surrounding Building No. 1 and is willing to
give that building to Senora Rojas to re-erect on a portion of Quinta
San Jose, some association should be formed to assure the permanent
preservation of the estate. I think necessarily this must be an
association chartered in Cuba but that its base can be broadened by
having a strong American representation. As I see it, Senora Rojas
would make provision that this association would receive the entire
estate, plus an endowment, for establishment as a Cuban-American mu-
seum. Informally, we shall be willing to participate in order to en-
courage such a movement and, within our means, offer direct technical
assistance upon request. In the near future, I shall outline the pro-
blem and the potential solutions from our point of view to Senora
Rojas.

In accordance with our understanding, I am enclosing a state-
ment of expenses incurred for the Jacksonville to Havana phase of my
recent trip. A check may be made out directly to the National Council
for Historic Sites and Buildings and is deductible for income tax pur-
poses. I shall take the liberty of considering it a contribution for
membership in the National Council during the forthcoming year.

I am very grateful to you for the opportunity presented, not
only to deal with a problem in this field, which may yet be solved, but
also to meet some fine people. I shall look forward to hearing from you
in the near future.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours Frederick L. Rath, Jr.
